titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Jean-François Bory Papers
titlestmt.author: by Ève Bourbeau-Allard

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 03:07

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.physdesc: 36 boxes + 2 cold storage, 1 record album storage
did.abstract: Writings, audiovisual works, photographic works, correspondence with literary colleagues, and other papers by or relating to French poet Jean-Franç̧ois Bory (1938- ). The materials document Bory's literary and artistic works across several genres and media, in particular his interest for visual poetry, sound poetry, film directing, and photomontage. Drafts, paste-ups, and proofs from literary projects, as well as production materials for the films SAGA (1967-1968) and Quant au livre (2004), provide evidence of Bory's creative process. Correspondence, article clippings, photographs of Bory, event programs, and promotional material for exhibitions trace his public career. Works of other avant-garde poets contemporary to Bory are represented in the collection by commercially-released CDs and DVDs of the multimedia label Son@rt, co-founded by Bory and fellow French poet Jacques Donguy.

langmaterial.language: Chiefly in French, with some material in English, Italian, and German.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: 28 (record album storage) and boxes 29-33 (audiovisual): Restricted fragile material. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.
34-35 (cold storage): Restricted fragile material. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.
Boxes 36-39 (computer media): Restricted fragile material. Reference copies of electronic files may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from the Librairie Patrick Fréchet on the Edwin J. Beinecke Book Fund, 2016.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into five series: I. Writings, circa 1960-2014. II. Audiovisual Works, 1957-2013. III. Photographic Works, 1974-2015. IV. Correspondence, 1972-2014. V. Professional Papers, 1965-2013.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Jean-François Bory (1938- ) is a French poet, writer, visual artist, and filmmaker whose avant-garde oeuvre centers on visual poetry and sound poetry.

Born in Paris, Bory spent part of his childhood in South East Asia before returning to the French capital where he based his career. In addition to numerous collections of poems, Bory's literary works include novels, monographs, essays, and articles of literary criticism.

The year 1966 marked Bory's first exhibits of visual poetry in London, Milan, and Venice. Two years later he participated in the pioneering sound poetry festival Text und Aktionsabend II in Bern. In 1983, Bory joined experimental poets Eugenio Miccini, Sarenco, Julien Blaine, Paul de Vree, and Alain Arias-Misson in forming the transnational group Logomotives. As part of his editing work, Bory co-founded the Éditions Agentzia (1968-1972) with Jochen Gerz and Arthur Hubschmid, directed the literary and sociological art magazine L'Humidité (1970-1975), and has served on the editorial board of CCP - Cahier critique de poésie since 1999. In 1998, Bory and avant-garde poet Jacques Donguy co-founded the production company and multimedia magazine Son@rt .

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Jean-François Bory Papers. General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, competing priorities, and whether or not further accruals are expected. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections as they are acquired, and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit. This collection received a basic level of processing, including rehousing and minimal organization. Information included in the Description of the Papers note and Collection Contents section is drawn from information supplied with the collection and from an initial survey of the contents. Folder titles appearing in the contents list below are often based on those provided by the creator or previous custodian. Titles have not been verified against the contents of the folders in all cases. Otherwise, folder titles are supplied by staff during initial processing. This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Writings, audiovisual works, photographic works, correspondence with literary colleagues, and other papers by or relating to French poet Jean-François Bory (1938- ). The materials document Bory's literary and artistic works across several genres and media, in particular his interest for visual poetry, sound poetry, film directing, and photomontage. Drafts, paste-ups, and proofs from literary projects, as well as production materials for the films SAGA (1967-1968) and Quant au livre (2004), provide evidence of Bory's creative process. Correspondence, article clippings, photographs of Bory, event programs, and promotional material for exhibitions trace his public career. Works of other avant-garde poets contemporary to Bory are represented in the collection by commercially-released CDs and DVDs of the multimedia label Son@rt, co-founded by Bory and fellow French poet Jacques Donguy.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Approximately 200 printed items received with the collection (including unannotated publications by Bory, exhibit catalogs, reference works, and substantial runs of published periodicals) were removed for separate cataloging on 01/30/2018 and can be accessed by searching the library's online catalog.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Jean-François Bory Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into four subseries: Books, Poems, Short Prose, and Edited and Translated Works.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I. Writings documents Bory's diverse literary production and creative process. The series comprises holograph drafts, typescripts, collages, paste-ups, proofs, cover designs, published texts in periodicals, and fragments for a comprehensive body of Bory's poetry collections, novels, monographs, individual poems, unpublished projects, and articles of art and literary criticism. Also included is one magazine maquette representing Bory's editing work for L'Humidité . From early drafts to published version, the types of material available for each writing project vary and are noted in file descriptions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Books subseries documents Bory's published and unpublished book-length projects, including poetry collections, novels, artist's books, and essays.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Poems subseries documents the creation and publication of individual poems composed by Bory through drafts, collages, proofs, and magazine issues. While Bory integrated most of these poems in the poetry collections found in the Books subseries, he also published them individually in literary magazines and reworked them over the years. The subseries also evidences the evolution of Bory's methodologies for creating visual poems, from mixed-material collages to printouts of digitally-created typographies and forms.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Edited and Translated Works subseries offers limited documentation of these facets of Bory's literary oeuvre, containing a partial translation by Bory of Brazilian concrete poet Augusto de Campos' "Galaxias", and material relating to Bory's 1970s experimental poetry magazine L'Humidité .

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into four subseries: Son@rt Productions, SAGA Film Archives, Quant au livre Film Archives, and Recordings.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Titles for non-commercial audiovisual and computer media have been transcribed from media labels. Inscriptions on the media's containers were not transcribed and may differ from the information found on the media itself. Audiovisual and computer media have not been viewed during processing. Description may change as media is reformatted.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II. Audiovisual Works contains audiovisual material, computer media, and analog files documenting Bory's sound poetry performances and film directing activities, the multimedia magazine Son@rt, as well as other experimental poets' works.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Sorted by material type under the headings Files and Media, and then arranged chronologically in publication order with corresponding Son@rt issue numbers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Son@rt Productions subseries include CDs and DVDs produced by Bory and Donguy's label Son@rt. Son@rt CDs and DVDs feature poetry readings, performances, reviews, and interviews by international artists.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The subseries comprises tapes, cassettes, non-commercial DVDs and CDs recording sound poetry performances by Bory, conferences to which Bory participated, and other films directed by Bory. Also included are commercially-released record albums and audio discs by Bory and other poets.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Published illustrations appear first in the series, followed by photographic postcards and prints.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series III contains photographic works created by Bory that relate to his poetic practice and that reflect his interest in collage, photomontage, and in the relation between text and image. Several pieces feature imagery of books and typewriters, a recurring theme in Bory's oeuvre. The series comprise magazine issues in which the photographs were published, as well as postcards and prints.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: See also: Series I. Writings, Jean-François Bory (Paris-Zurich: Hubschmid, 1974) (Box 5, Folder 41) for an artist's book composed entirely of photomontages.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The correspondence is aggregated alphabetically by the first letter of correspondents' last names. A note for each file identifies all correspondents.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series IV. Correspondence, contains letters sent to Bory, with few or no copies of his replies. Largely of a professional nature, the correspondence documents other literary figures' and acquaintances' reactions to Bory's works and collaboration between them. The series contains a handful of letters from each of the one hundred or so correspondents. More substantial correspondence (five letters or more) is present for the following individuals: Marc Dachy, Jérôme Duwa, Bernard Heidsieck, Michèle Métail, Pierre Mréjen, Claude Royet-Journoud, and Sarenco.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into four subseries: Portraits of Bory, Reviews and Articles about Bory, Promotional Material and Event Publications, and Other Print Material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series V. Professional Papers, traces Bory's career through promotional material, programs, and anthologies for exhibits, events, and performances to which he participated. Also included are reviews and articles written about Bory by other authors, as well as photographic portraits capturing him at work.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Box 29 (audiovisual): Restricted fragile material. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged chronologically by publication date, apart from a group of clippings received as one file.

arrangement.p: Arranged chronologically and listed by document types and publication titles.

scopecontent.p: Contains twenty promotional posters for events, exhibits, or publications; and four large size prints of visual poems: "Errata", "Hommage à Pavlov", and [untitled] by Bory, and [untitled] by Irine Schwartz.
